section.heading: Purpose and Scope.
section.text: This chapter describes the procedures of the support enforcement agency to enforce compliance with the terms of child support orders under its supervision.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

"Earnings withholding notice" means a notice in a format prescribed by federal law issued by the administration to an employer requiring the employer to deduct support payments from the earnings of an obligor.

"Earnings withholding order" means an order in a format prescribed by federal law issued by a tribunal to an employer requiring the employer to deduct support payments from the earnings of an obligor.

"Garnishment" means a legal proceeding by which a noncustodial parent's property, money, or money owed the noncustodial parent is withheld from the noncustodial parent or a third party and applied to the payment of the noncustodial parent's child support obligation.
"IRS full collection service" means a program in which the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) collects arrears on child support obligations for the Administration.

section.heading: Monitoring.
section.text: The support enforcement agency shall review, at least once a month, the payment status of each case for which it is responsible.

section.heading: Enforcement of the Child Support Obligation.

para.text: The support enforcement agency shall:
Enforce each obligation for which payment is delinquent in an amount equal to the support payment for 1 month;
Take appropriate enforcement action within 30 days of identifying a delinquency or the location of the noncustodial parent, whichever occurs later; and
Take appropriate action to enforce a health insurance enrollment order.
If service of process is necessary before enforcement action, the support enforcement agency shall:
Complete service and take enforcement action within 60 days of identifying the delinquency or locating the noncustodial parent, whichever occurs later; or
In cases where service of process is not completed, document unsuccessful attempts to serve the noncustodial parent.
To enable the support enforcement agency to properly enforce the order, the custodial parent shall notify the support enforcement agency when the child:
Marries;
Becomes 18 years old and is enrolled in secondary school;
Otherwise emancipates; or
Dies.
Earnings Withholding. The support enforcement agency shall issue an earnings withholding notice in accordance with COMAR 07.07.19 for:
Civil child support orders; and
Criminal nonsupport orders.
Noncustodial Parent Contact. The support enforcement agency may contact the noncustodial parent, by telephone or mail, to negotiate a lump sum payment or a payment plan to pay the arrears.
Court Action.
The support enforcement agency may initiate contempt proceedings against the noncustodial parent when the noncustodial parent accumulates more than 30 days arrears.

When an arrearage exists under a child support order issued in a criminal nonsupport proceeding, the support enforcement agency shall notify the attorney for the support enforcement agency of the arrearage not later than 60 days before the expiration of the order.
The support enforcement agency may request that the attorney for the support enforcement agency provide all necessary legal services for:
Garnishing financial accounts and attaching assets of the noncustodial parent;
Securing a performance bond; and
Using any other form of legal process considered appropriate.
IRS Full Collection Service. The support enforcement agency may apply for collection by the IRS, when the support enforcement agency documents that:
There are arrears equal to or exceeding $750;
Local, State, and intergovernmental enforcement efforts have failed; and
The noncustodial parent has known assets.

Lien Against Real Property. The support enforcement agency may file a notice of a child support lien with the clerk of a circuit court under Family Law Article, §10-141, Annotated Code of Maryland, if:
The noncustodial parent is in arrears for a child support obligation in an amount exceeding $500;
The unpaid child support constitutes a lien under Family Law Article, §10-140, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Real property deeded to the noncustodial parent has been identified and the noncustodial parent's ownership interest in the property has been verified.
Garnishment of Financial Accounts. The support enforcement agency may initiate action to garnish the financial account of a noncustodial parent under Maryland Rule 2-645, if:
The noncustodial parent owes at least $500 arrears; and
The support enforcement agency has verified that the noncustodial parent has ownership interest in the account.
Performance Bond. The support enforcement agency may request that a court order a noncustodial parent to post a bond to ensure consistent payment of a child support obligation if:
The noncustodial parent owes at least $500 arrears;
Financial accounts of the noncustodial parent cannot be garnished;
Financial accounts of the noncustodial parent have sufficient value to satisfy:
All arrears owed; or
A portion of the arrears equal to 6 months of the support ordered amount;
The noncustodial parent is:
Self-employed; or
Earnings withholding has not been effective;
The noncustodial parent's payment history has been poor as evidenced by:
Irregular payments; or
Payments less than the support ordered amount; and
The noncustodial parent is out of compliance with the most recent support order.
National Medical Support Notice (NMSN). The support enforcement agency shall issue a NMSN in accordance with COMAR 07.07.20 to enforce the medical support provisions of a child support order.
Other Remedies. The support enforcement agency shall initiate other enforcement remedies as provided for in this subtitle.
Cooperate with child support enforcement agencies of other states to secure compliance with court orders for child support;
Use all appropriate enforcement methods in intergovernmental cases that the support enforcement agency uses in intrastate cases;
Initiate intergovernmental earnings withholding procedures when an obligor is liable for earnings withholding and the obligor's employer:
Is located outside the State, and
Has no agent in the State; and
Comply with the provisions of UIFSA.
